subtasks: Identify optimal pruning time (winter/dormant season)
Understand the effects of winter pruning (increase growth/vigor)
Distinguish between winter and summer pruning methods
Evaluate tree form and structure for improvement
Trim dead, damaged, or shaded branches
Thin out dense canopy areas
Thinning vigorous, lanky shoots to enhance fruit production
Prune espalier trees for structured growth and fruit production
Manage height of overly tall trees by selective pruning
Consider summer pruning for better control and fruit set
Wait until before bud break to prune grapes
Retain spurs and cut them back to 1-2 buds
Thin grape shoots for better airflow and fruit production
Remove lanky, vigorous shoots from stone fruit trees
Thin fruit buds to prevent overcrowding
Encourage branching at lower heights for easier harvesting
Form a vase or umbrella shape for better light penetration
Address specific fruiting habits (e.g., peaches on last year's growth) in pruning strategy
Inspect trees for signs of disease or pest infestation (mentioned in context but not extensively detailed)
Prepare orchard equipment/supplies for continued maintenance
Note the importance of continual monitoring and adjustment of pruning techniques
